elements.content: Adsorption equilibrium and diffusion of benzene on mesoporous chromium−terphthalate-based crystals (MIL-101) were experimentally studied by the gravimetric method in the pressure range up to 60.0 mbar. The MIL-101 crystals, whose sizes are about 100 nm, were synthesized by using microwave irradiation method. Adsorption isotherms and kinetic curves of benzene on the MIL-101 were measured experimentally. Results show that the maximum amount adsorbed of benzene on the synthesized MIL-101 was up to 16.5 mmol/g (or 176 wt %) at 288 K and 56.0 mbar. Diffusion coefficients of benzene within the MIL-101 were in the range of (4.25−4.76) × 10−9 cm2/s in 288−318 K with a lower activation energy of 2.41 kJ/mol. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) curves exhibited two separated peaks corresponding to two types of major adsorption sites for benzene adsorption on MIL-101. Consecutive cycles of adsorption−desorption experiment showed a fast desorption kinetics and high reversibility for benzene adsorption on MIL-101. The efficiency of benzene desorption from MIL-101 can reach 97%.

elements.content: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are a large group of anthropogenic (xenobiotic) or biogenic organic compounds with relatively high vapor pressures. Most of the VOCs emitted by chemical materials, such as solvents, resins, adhesives, and paints used for building materials and furniture are very harmful to the environment and human health. In these compounds, benzene is a typical and major indoor air pollutant, which has already been shown to cause leukemia and other cancers in humans with long-term exposure. Therefore, the research on the removal of VOCs has attracted increasing attention during the past decade.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are a large group of anthropogenic (xenobiotic) or biogenic organic compounds with relatively high vapor pressures. Most of the VOCs emitted by chemical materials, such as solvents, resins, adhesives, and paints used for building materials and furniture are very harmful to the environment and human health. In these compounds, benzene is a typical and major indoor air pollutant, which has already been shown to cause leukemia and other cancers in humans with long-term exposure. Therefore, the research on the removal of VOCs has attracted increasing attention during the past decade.

elements.content: There are many techniques available to abate the emission of VOCs (destruction based and recovery based), such as adsorption, thermal or catalytic oxidation, condensation, membrane separation, and biological treatments. Adsorption is generally considered to be a fast, safe, and economically feasible method to remove VOCs from indoor air in low concentration, especially for trace amounts of VOCs. The crucial aspect in the process is the appropriate choice of a suitable adsorbent. Identifying an adsorbent which adsorbs and releases VOCs with high capacity, fast kinetics and high reversibility over multiple cycles is the key to the development of the viable adsorption process for VOCs sorptive removal. Besides, high thermal and chemical stability with permanent porosity are an important parameter that influences selection of an adsorbent candidate.

The crucial aspect in the process is the appropriate choice of a suitable adsorbent. Identifying an adsorbent which adsorbs and releases VOCs with high capacity, fast kinetics and high reversibility over multiple cycles is the key to the development of the viable adsorption process for VOCs sorptive removal. Besides, high thermal and chemical stability with permanent porosity are an important parameter that influences selection of an adsorbent candidate.

elements.content: Activated carbon and zeolites have been for a long time strategic materials for VOCs treatment from polluted air and industrial waste gases due to their pore textual properties, low operation cost, and high efficiency. Moon et al. prepared a corn-grain-based monolith for adsorption of benzene and toluene and reported that a high benzene capacity of 12.68 mmol/g by a reduction of excess void volumes as well as the level of mesopores in this material was available. Hernadez studied the adsorption properties of Ag-doped SiO2 for aromatic BTX hydrocarbons (benzene, toluene, and p-xylene). His experimental results showed that the adsorbed amounts of BTX hydrocarbons were increased on SiO2 after modifying by Ag due to the enhanced interaction between BTX molecules with modified adsorbent.

Moon et al. prepared a corn-grain-based monolith for adsorption of benzene and toluene and reported that a high benzene capacity of 12.68 mmol/g by a reduction of excess void volumes as well as the level of mesopores in this material was available. Hernadez studied the adsorption properties of Ag-doped SiO2 for aromatic BTX hydrocarbons (benzene, toluene, and p-xylene). elements.content: Recently, some novel materials with higher surface area, larger pore volume, and more uniform structure are being developed for VOCs treatment. Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) represent a fundamentally new class of nanoporous material. The crystalline porous materials are constructed from transition ions and bridging organic ligand, which have a vast, sturdy, and uniform framework structure. Owing to their extrahigh porosity and ordered and adjustable chemical functionality, MOFs now have the potential to various applications of gas storage, separations, and heterogeneous catalysis, especially in adsorption area. MIL-101 (Matérial Institut Lavoisier, chromium−terphthalate-based solid), a recent addition to MOFs, showed an extrahigh specific surface area and pore volume with the framework structure of microporous apertures and mesoporous cages. Additionally, this material was reported to be very stable at high temperature (up to 473K) and in the presence of different organic solvents (including water). Therefore, MIL-101 is attracting more attention in the potential application of gas adsorption. Férey et al. carried out high-pressure CO2 adsorption studies on MIL-101. The uptake of CO2 in MIL-101 has been shown to occur with a record capacity of 40 mmol/g at 5 MPa and 303 K. Chang et al. reported the benzene adsorption equilibrium on MIL-101 and revealed that this material had an intricate structure and demonstrates a huge, rapid adsorption of benzene, making it a good candidate for the removal of some harmful organic contaminants. However, no experimental data on diffusivities of organic compound in MIL-101 are available in the literature.

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) represent a fundamentally new class of nanoporous material. The crystalline porous materials are constructed from transition ions and bridging organic ligand, which have a vast, sturdy, and uniform framework structure. Owing to their extrahigh porosity and ordered and adjustable chemical functionality, MOFs now have the potential to various applications of gas storage, separations, and heterogeneous catalysis, especially in adsorption area. MIL-101 (Matérial Institut Lavoisier, chromium-terphthalate-based solid), a recent addition to MOFs, showed an extrahigh specific surface area and pore volume with the framework structure of microporous apertures and mesoporous cages. Additionally, this material was reported to be very stable at high temperature (up to 473K) and in the presence of different organic solvents (including water). Therefore, MIL-101 is attracting more attention in the potential application of gas adsorption. Férey et al. carried out high-pressure CO2 adsorption studies on MIL-101. The uptake of CO2 in MIL-101 has been shown to occur with a record capacity of 40 mmol/g at 5 MPa and 303 K. Chang et al. reported the benzene adsorption equilibrium on MIL-101 and revealed that this material had an intricate structure and demonstrates a huge, rapid adsorption of benzene, making it a good candidate for the removal of some harmful organic contaminants. However, no experimental data on diffusivities of organic compound in MIL-101 are available in the literature.

elements.content: The purpose of this work is to investigate the adsorption equilibrium and diffusion kinetics of benzene on MIL-101. The nanosized MIL-101 crystals were synthesized using microwave irradiation. Then the adsorption equilibrium and kinetics properties of benzene on MIL-101 were measured by a gravimetric method for estimation of diffusion coefficients of benzene. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) experiments of benzene on MIL-101 were carried out for estimation of the binding energy between MIL-101 and benzene. With the help of consecutive cycles of benzene adsorption−desorption experiments, the reversibility of benzene adsorption−desorption on MIL-101 will be discussed and reported.
elements.clean_text: The purpose of this work is to investigate the adsorption equilibrium and diffusion kinetics of benzene on MIL-101. The nanosized MIL-101 crystals were synthesized using microwave irradiation. Then the adsorption equilibrium and kinetics properties of benzene on MIL-101 were measured by a gravimetric method for estimation of diffusion coefficients of benzene. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) experiments of benzene on MIL-101 were carried out for estimation of the binding energy between MIL-101 and benzene. With the help of consecutive cycles of benzene adsorption-desorption experiments, the reversibility of benzene adsorption-desorption on MIL-101 will be discussed and reported.

elements.content: Chromium(III) nitrate nonahydrate (Cr(NO3)3·9H2O, >99.0%, from Tianjin), 1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, ≥99.0%, Acros Organic), and hydrofluoric acid (HF, 48%, from Merck) were used as received from vendors without further purification. The chromium−terephthalate MIL-101 was synthesized at 493 K for 60 min under microwave irradiation at 300 W. The molar composition of the reactant mixture was Cr(NO3)3·9H2O:H2BDC:HF:H2O 1:1:1:278. The reactant mixture was loaded into a Teflon autoclave, sealed, and placed in a microwave oven (Mars-5, CEM). The autoclave was heated to 493 K in 15 min and kept at this temperature for 60 min. After the reaction time, the reactor was cooled to room temperature. A fine green colored powder was obtained as the major product. To obtain high porosity, the as-synthesized MIL-101 was purified by using the reported method. Contents were completely transferred into a conical flask, and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, >99%, from Mallinckrodt) was added incrementally with continuous shaking to dissolve the H2BDC. By repeating washing with DMF and centrifugation, most of the terephthalic acid was removed from MIL-101. However, a significant amount of free H2BDC within the pores of MIL-101 was still found. To remove this extra H2BDC from the pores, an additional ethanol (>99.7, from Tianjin Fuyu) rinse was performed. About 400 mg of MIL-101 powder and 30 mL of ethanol were placed in an autoclave at 393 K for 20 h. After cooling, the resulting product was centrifuged and washed with ethanol. Finally, the product was dried at 423 K overnight.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Sections

Synthesis of MIL-101

Chromium(III) nitrate nonahydrate (Cr(NO3)3⋅9H2O, >99.0%, from Tianjin), 1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, ≥99.0%, Acros Organic), and hydrofluoric acid (HF, 48%, from Merck) were used as received from vendors without further purification. The chromium-terephthalate MIL-101 was synthesized at 493 K for 60 min under microwave irradiation at 300 W. The molar composition of the reactant mixture was Cr(NO3)3⋅9H2O:H2BDC:HF:H2O 1:1:1:278. The reactant mixture was loaded into a Teflon autoclave, sealed, and placed in a microwave oven (Mars-5, CEM). The autoclave was heated to 493 K in 15 min and kept at this temperature for 60 min. After the reaction time, the reactor was cooled to room temperature. A fine green colored powder was obtained as the major product. To obtain high porosity, the as-synthesized MIL-101 was purified by using the reported method. Contents were completely transferred into a conical flask, and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, >99%, from Mallinckrodt) was added incrementally with continuous shaking to dissolve the H2BDC. By repeating washing with DMF and centrifugation, most of the terephthalic acid was removed from MIL-101. However, a significant amount of free H2BDC within the pores of MIL-101 was still found. To remove this extra H2BDC from the pores, an additional ethanol (>99.7, from Tianjin Fuyu) rinse was performed. About 400 mg of MIL-101 powder and 30 mL of ethanol were placed in an autoclave at 393 K for 20 h. After cooling, the resulting product was centrifuged and washed with ethanol. Finally, the product was dried at 423 K overnight.

elements.content: The surface morphology and particle size of the crystalline MIL-101 samples were observed by a Philips FEI XL-30 scanning electron microscope (SEM) at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV after gold deposition. X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterization was carried out on D/max-IIIA diffratometer (Rigaku Co.) operating at 35 kV and 25 mA by using Cu Kα1 radiation (λ = 1.540 56). Nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured by a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 adsorption porosimeter at liquid nitrogen temperature of 77 K. The sample was prepared at 150 °C for 3 h under vacuum. The surface areas were calculated using the Langmuir and Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) methods and the pore size was calculated using the Barrett−Joyner−Hatenda (BJH) model.
elements.clean_text:
Materials Characterization

The surface morphology and particle size of the crystalline MIL-101 samples were observed by a Philips FEI XL-30 scanning electron microscope (SEM) at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV after gold deposition. X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterization was carried out on D/max-IIIA diffratometer (Rigaku Co.) operating at 35 kV and 25 mA by using Cu Kα1 radiation (λ = 1.54056). Nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured by a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 adsorption porosimeter at liquid nitrogen temperature of 77 K. The sample was prepared at 150 °C for 3 h under vacuum. The surface areas were calculated using the Langmuir and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) methods and the pore size was calculated using the Barrett-Joyner-Hatenda (BJH) model.

elements.content: An intelligent gravimetric analyzer (IGA-003, HIDEN) was used to measure the benzene adsorption isotherms for the MIL-101 samples. In IGA-003, an ultrasensitive microbalance of resolution 0.2 μg is mounted in the thermostated heatsink with high precision temperature control. The sample weighed about 50−60 mg for each run. Before the measurements, the sample in the vessel of IGA-003 was vacuumed up to 3−5 Pa and outgassed at 423 K for 5 h. The measurements were carried out from 288 to 318 K in terms of the built-in water baths. The highest adsorption pressure was up to 60.0 mbar. The adsorption uptake of benzene on MIL-101 was calculated as follows: Q e = 1000 ( W e − W a ) W a M benzene Q t = 1000 ( W t − W a ) W a M benzene where M benzene (g/mol) is the molecular weight of benzene molecule, W e (g) and W t (g) are the amount of adsorbent (the MIL-101) at equilibrium and time t (s), W a is the initial weight of the MIL-101, and Q e (mmol/g) and Q t (mmol/g) are the amount of adsorbed per gram at equilibrium and at time t (s), respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Benzene Vapor Adsorption Experiments

An intelligent gravimetric analyzer (IGA-003, HIDEN) was used to measure the benzene adsorption isotherms for the MIL-101 samples. In IGA-003, an ultrasensitive microbalance of resolution 0.2 μg is mounted in the thermostated heatsink with high precision temperature control. The sample weighed about 50-60 mg for each run. Before the measurements, the sample in the vessel of IGA-003 was vacuumed up to 3-5 Pa and outgassed at 423 K for 5 h. The measurements were carried out from 288 to 318 K in terms of the built-in water baths. The highest adsorption pressure was up to 60.0 mbar. The adsorption uptake of benzene on MIL-101 was calculated as follows: 1    Q   e   =   1000  (    W   e   -   W   a    )      W   a     M   benzene        2    Q   t   =   1000  (    W   t   -   W   a    )      W   a     M   benzene      where M benzene (g/mol) is the molecular weight of benzene molecule, W e (g) and W  t  (g) are the amount of adsorbent (the MIL-101) at equilibrium and time t (s), W a is the initial weight of the MIL-101, and Q e (mmol/g) and Q  t  (mmol/g) are the amount of adsorbed per gram at equilibrium and at time t (s), respectively.

elements.content: A temperature programmed desorption experiment was conducted on a gas chromatography workstation (GC-9560, Haixin Co.) as shown in Figure . The TPD experiments were conducted at different heating rates from 2 to 6 K/min. In each experiment, the samples that had adsorbed the benzene vapor were packed in a stainless steel reaction tube whose inner diameter was 0.3 cm and whose packed length was 0.5 cm. Subsequently, the stainless steel tube was placed in a reaction furnace and then heated in the high-purity N2 flow at a constant rate of 50 mL/min. The desorbed benzene vapor was measured by using the GC-9560 chromatograph with a flame ionization detector (FID) at the outlet of the stainless steel reaction tube, and effluent curves were recorded, which were called the desorption (TPD) curves. According to the experimental TPD curves, the application of eq can estimate the desorption activation energy of benzene on MIL-101.
elements.clean_text:
Temperature Programmed Desorption Experiments

A temperature programmed desorption experiment was conducted on a gas chromatography workstation (GC-9560, Haixin Co.) as shown in Figure . The TPD experiments were conducted at different heating rates from 2 to 6 K/min. In each experiment, the samples that had adsorbed the benzene vapor were packed in a stainless steel reaction tube whose inner diameter was 0.3 cm and whose packed length was 0.5 cm. Subsequently, the stainless steel tube was placed in a reaction furnace and then heated in the high-purity N2 flow at a constant rate of 50 mL/min. The desorbed benzene vapor was measured by using the GC-9560 chromatograph with a flame ionization detector (FID) at the outlet of the stainless steel reaction tube, and effluent curves were recorded, which were called the desorption (TPD) curves. According to the experimental TPD curves, the application of eq  can estimate the desorption activation energy of benzene on MIL-101.

elements.content: Figure shows the SEM image of the MIL-101 sample synthesized by using the microwave irradiation method. The image indicates a clear octahedral morphology for the MIL-101 crystallized product. The crystal sizes of the MIL-101 are more uniform and have smaller dimensions in comparison with the MIL-101 synthesized by using solvothermal method. The crystal size range of this MIL-101 is approximately 70−100 nm, which is about 10 times smaller than the MIL-101 synthesized by using the solvent−thermal method reported in previous literature.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Physical Characteristics

Figure  shows the SEM image of the MIL-101 sample synthesized by using the microwave irradiation method. The image indicates a clear octahedral morphology for the MIL-101 crystallized product. The crystal sizes of the MIL-101 are more uniform and have smaller dimensions in comparison with the MIL-101 synthesized by using solvothermal method. The crystal size range of this MIL-101 is approximately 70-100 nm, which is about 10 times smaller than the MIL-101 synthesized by using the solvent-thermal method reported in previous literature.

elements.content: Table shows the textural properties of the MIL-101 samples synthesized in this work. In addition, it also lists the textural parameters of the MIL-101 samples synthesized by other groups for comparison. It indicates that there are some differences between the surface area and the pore volume results obtained in this work and those in other works reported in the literature. This may be attributed to the application of different synthesis methods and also to the presence of varying degrees of residual terephthalic acid and guest molecules. It is noticed that the MIL-101 synthesized by using microwave irradiation has a slightly larger surface area and pore volume in comparison with the samples synthesized by the solvothermal method.

Figure shows adsorption isotherms of benzene vapor on the MIL-101 at different temperatures from 288 to 318 K measured experimentally. The experimental data show a type-I profile with a sharp increase in the uptake (at low benzene relative pressure) followed by a plateau. The maximum amount of adsorbed benzene is about 16.5 mmol/g at 288 K and 56.0 mbar. The adsorption capacity of benzene on the MIL-101 decreases with temperature, indicating a physisorption between benzene and MIL-101.

Adsorption Isotherms of Benzene on MIL-101

Figure  shows adsorption isotherms of benzene vapor on the MIL-101 at different temperatures from 288 to 318 K measured experimentally. The experimental data show a type-I profile with a sharp increase in the uptake (at low benzene relative pressure) followed by a plateau. The maximum amount of adsorbed benzene is about 16.5 mmol/g at 288 K and 56.0 mbar. The adsorption capacity of benzene on the MIL-101 decreases with temperature, indicating a physisorption between benzene and MIL-101.

elements.content: Table lists the equilibrium amount of benzene adsorbed on the MIL-101 synthesized in this work and some adsorbents. It can be seen that the amount of benzene adsorbed on the MIL-101 synthesized in this work or by Férey group is much higher than the other adsorbents, such as ACF, carbon monolith, silicalite-1, and so on. Compared with these commercial porous materials, the MIL-101 sample has extralarge surface area and large pore volume, which will improve its adsorption capacity of benzene. Meanwhile, π−π interaction can be formed by benzene molecules and benzene rings in the linker for the MIL-101 when benzene is adsorbed, which is stronger than the C−π and O−π interactions between benzene molecules and carbon materials or zeolites. As a consequence of that, it increases the adsorption capacity of the MIL-101 toward benzene.

It is also noticed that the equilibrium adsorption capacity of the MIL-101 synthesized in this work for benzene is very close to that of the MIL-101 sample reported by Férey group.

Adsorption Kinetics of Benzene on the MIL-101 Samples

Adsorption kinetics of benzene on MIL-101 has hardly been reported. Figure shows the fractional adsorption kinetic curves of benzene on MIL-101 at various benzene vapor pressures. As shown, the fractional transient uptake of benzene on the MIL-101 samples at different pressures ranging from 30 to 78 mbar are essentially the same, indicating that benzene loading has a negligible effect on the diffusivity of benzene within the MIL-101 samples.

Adsorption Kinetics of Benzene on the MIL-101 Samples

Adsorption kinetics of benzene on MIL-101 has hardly been reported. Figure  shows the fractional adsorption kinetic curves of benzene on MIL-101 at various benzene vapor pressures. As shown, the fractional transient uptake of benzene on the MIL-101 samples at different pressures ranging from 30 to 78 mbar are essentially the same, indicating that benzene loading has a negligible effect on the diffusivity of benzene within the MIL-101 samples.

elements.clean_text: 6  Fractional transient uptakes of benzene on MIL-101 at different feed pressures (at 288 K).

elements.content: Figure shows fractional transient uptakes of benzene on the MIL-101 samples at different temperatures. According to these kinetic uptake curves, the intracrystalline diffusion coefficient of benzene within the MIL-101 sample can be estimated. Assuming that adsorbent is a spherical particle, the transient fractional uptakes can be described by the following equation in the region with fractional uptake Q t /Q e less than 70%: Q t Q e ≅ 6 r c D M t π where D M (cm2/s) is the intracrystalline diffusion coefficient and r c (cm) is the particle radius. If the adsorption kinetic experiment of benzene is conducted at a certain pressure, the corresponding kinetic curve, the Q t −t curve, could be obtained. After that, a plot of Q t /Q e versus t 1/2 will yield a line with slope 6/r c(D M/π)1/2. As a result, from the slope of the line, the diffusion time constant (D M/r c 2, s−1) and diffusion coefficient D M can be found.

It can be seen that the plots were linearly fitted with correlation coefficients (R) of more than 0.99, as shown in Figure , indicating that the benzene diffusion within the MIL-101 can be well-described by eq . From the slopes of these lines, the diffusion time constants and diffusion coefficients of benzene on the MIL-101 samples were obtained, as listed in Table .

The data in Table indicate that the diffusion time constants (D M/r c 2) of benzene on MIL-101 are in range of (1.70−1.87) × 10−2 s−1. The corresponding diffusion coefficient (D M) is in the range of (1.70−1.87) × 10−9 cm2/s on the basis of the average particle radius r c of 5 μm, and the diffusion coefficient (D M) increases with temperature under the studied conditions. Benzene diffusion in MIL-101 is found to be an activated process.

elements.content: According to the Arrhenius equation, suppose that the relationship between the diffusion coefficient of benzene (D M) and the activation energy for benzene adsorption on the MIL-101, E a, can be described as follows: D M = A exp ( − E / a R T ) where A is the rate coefficient. Equation can also be expressed as ln D M = ln A − ( E a / R T ) When ln D M is plotted versus 1/T, a straight line with slope −E a/R is available. The activation energy E a can be directly calculated from the slope.

Equation  can also be expressed as 5  ln    D   M   = ln  A - (   E   a   / R T )  When ln D M is plotted versus 1/T, a straight line with slope -E a/R is available. The activation energy E a can be directly calculated from the slope.

elements.content: Figure shows the linear dependences between ln D M and 1/T for benzene diffusing in the MIL-101 crystals. From the slope of the straight line, the activation energy (E a) of benzene diffusion in the MIL-101 is obtained, which is about 2.41 kJ/mol.

The data in Table indicate that the diffusion coefficient of benzene in the MIL-101 sample is about 4−10 times higher than that in zeolites (ZSM-5 and in silicalite-1) and 5 times higher than that in activated carbon.

The MIL-101 has a mesoporous zeotype architecture topology with two types of mesoporous cages of ∼29 and 34 Å, respectively. The smaller cages exhibit pentagonal windows with a free opening of ∼12 Å, while the large cages possess both pentagonal and larger hexagonal windows with a ∼14.5 Å by 16 Å free aperture. Compared to the zeolites and activated carbons, the MIL-101 has a larger pore distribution and opening channel structure. Its opening apertures and larger channels can greatly decrease the diffusion resistances of benzene in the porous particles and thus obtain fast adsorption kinetics. In addition, the activation energy for benzene diffusion in the MIL-101 is much smaller than that in the zeolites and activated carbons, as shown in Table , suggesting that benzene diffusion in the MIL-101 is much easier in comparison with that in the zeolites and activated carbons. Xiao and Wei showed that the activation energy for diffusion decreases with decreasing ratio of the kinetic diameter of diffusing molecule to the pore opening of porous materials (λ = d m/d p). In this case, the λ = d m/d p is 0.43−0.38 for MIL-101 and is around 1 for ZSM-5 and silicalite-1. The MIL-101 has smaller activation energy for benzene diffusion due to its λ = d m/d p being smaller compared to that of the ZSM-5 and silicalite-1, and thus benzene diffusion would be faster than that in the ZSM-5 and silicalite-1, which is consistent with the theory of Xiao and Wei.

Its opening apertures and larger channels can greatly decrease the diffusion resistances of benzene in the porous particles and thus obtain fast adsorption kinetics. In addition, the activation energy for benzene diffusion in the MIL-101 is much smaller than that in the zeolites and activated carbons, as shown in Table , suggesting that benzene diffusion in the MIL-101 is much easier in comparison with that in the zeolites and activated carbons. Xiao and Wei showed that the activation energy for diffusion decreases with decreasing ratio of the kinetic diameter of diffusing molecule to the pore opening of porous materials (λ = d m/d p). In this case, the λ = d m/d p is 0.43-0.38 for MIL-101 and is around 1 for ZSM-5 and silicalite-1. The MIL-101 has smaller activation energy for benzene diffusion due to its λ = d m/d p being smaller compared to that of the ZSM-5 and silicalite-1, and thus benzene diffusion would be faster than that in the ZSM-5 and silicalite-1, which is consistent with the theory of Xiao and Wei.

elements.content: Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) is a technique of material surface analysis and can be used to estimate binding energy between the adsorbate and adsorbent. In a TPD experiment, a GC or a mass spectrometer is used to measure the rate at which the adsorbate desorbs from the adsorbent. Using the TPD curves, we can know how strongly molecules are bound to the surface of the adsorbent. TPD curves can be described by the Polanyi−Wigner equation r d = − d θ A d t = k o θ A n exp ( − E d / R T ) where r d is the desorption rate (mol/s), θA is the fractional surface coverage, E d is the desorption activation energy of adsorbate (kJ/mol), n is the order of the desorption process, R is the gas constant [8.314J/(K·mol)], and k o is a constant that depends on the desorption kinetics (s−1). The desorption process can be assumed to follow first-order kinetics, n is equal to 1, and the desorption activation energy of the adsorbate can be calculated by ln ( β H R T p 2 ) = − ( E d R T p ) − ln ( E d k o ) where βH is the heating rate (K/min) and T p is the peak desorption temperature (K).
elements.clean_text:
Desorption Activation Energies of Benzene on MIL-101

Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) is a technique of material surface analysis and can be used to estimate binding energy between the adsorbate and adsorbent. In a TPD experiment, a GC or a mass spectrometer is used to measure the rate at which the adsorbate desorbs from the adsorbent. Using the TPD curves, we can know how strongly molecules are bound to the surface of the adsorbent. TPD curves can be described by the Polanyi-Wigner equation 6    r   d   = -   d   θ   A     d t   =   k   o       θ   A     n    exp ( -   E   d   / R T )  where r d is the desorption rate (mol/s), θA is the fractional surface coverage, E d is the desorption activation energy of adsorbate (kJ/mol), n is the order of the desorption process, R is the gas constant [8.314J/(K⋅mol)], and k o is a constant that depends on the desorption kinetics (s-1). The desorption process can be assumed to follow first-order kinetics, n is equal to 1, and the desorption activation energy of the adsorbate can be calculated by  7  ln  (     β   H     R     T   p     2     )  = -  (     E   d     R   T   p     )  - ln  (     E   d       k   o     )   where βH is the heating rate (K/min) and T p is the peak desorption temperature (K).

elements.content: Figure shows the TPD spectra of benzene from the MIL-101 at the heating rate of 2 K/min. It clearly indicates that there a separated peaks in the TPD curve of benzene on the MIL-101, suggesting heterogeneity for benzene adsorption on the MIL-101 frameworks. These two peaks are separately corresponding to two major sites in the MIL-101 for benzene adsorption: one appearing at the lower temperature exhibits the weaker adsorption sites, while the other appearing at the higher temperature exhibits the stronger adsorption sites. Generally speaking, the strong interactions would occur between the Cr3+ metal centers and the adsorbate molecules, and the slightly weaker interactions occur between the space of the framework pores and the adsorbate molecules.

elements.content: On the other hand, the peak area of the TPD curve represents the amount of benzene desorbed from the MIL-101. The larger peak area of the TPD curve meant that more benzene desorbed from the MIL-101. It is also noticed from Figure that the area of the first peak is much larger than that of the second one. This suggests that the amount of benzene adsorbed on the sites of MIL-101 framework pores is much higher than that on Cr3+ metal center sites because the sites of the Cr3+ metal centers can be poisoned by some residual terephthalic acid, guest molecules, or other solvent molecules (e.g., ethanol and DMF) trapped inside the cavities of MIL-101.

elements.content: In this work, the profiles of benzene TPD curves obtained at different heating rates all have two separated peaks. Figure shows the TPD spectra of benzene on the MIL-101 samples at different heating rates from 2 to 6 K/min (N2 flow rate 50 mL/min): Figure a shows the first peaks of TPD curves at lower temperatures, and Figure b shows the second peaks of the TPD curves at higher temperatures. Knowing the values of each T p (T p(1) and T p(2)) at different heating rates, two desorption activation energies E d (E d(1) and E d(2)) corresponding to two kinds of adsorption sites in the MIL-101 sample can be estimated by employing eq .

elements.content: Figure shows the variation curve of the amounts of benzene adsorbed on the MIL-101 obtained from five consecutive cycles of benzene adsorption−desorption experiments at 288 K. cln_elements.content: Chromium(III) nitrate nonahydrate (Cr(NO3)3·9H2O, >99.0%, from Tianjin), 1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, ≥99.0%, Acros Organic), and hydrofluoric acid (HF, 48%, from Merck) were used as received from vendors without further purification. The chromium−terephthalate MIL-101 was synthesized at 493 K for 60 min under microwave irradiation at 300 W. The molar composition of the reactant mixture was Cr(NO3)3·9H2O:H2BDC:HF:H2O 1:1:1:278. The reactant mixture was loaded into a Teflon autoclave, sealed, and placed in a microwave oven (Mars-5, CEM). The autoclave was heated to 493 K in 15 min and kept at this temperature for 60 min. After the reaction time, the reactor was cooled to room temperature. A fine green colored powder was obtained as the major product. To obtain high porosity, the as-synthesized MIL-101 was purified by using the reported method. Contents were completely transferred into a conical flask, and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, >99%, from Mallinckrodt) was added incrementally with continuous shaking to dissolve the H2BDC. By repeating washing with DMF and centrifugation, most of the terephthalic acid was removed from MIL-101. However, a significant amount of free H2BDC within the pores of MIL-101 was still found. To remove this extra H2BDC from the pores, an additional ethanol (>99.7, from Tianjin Fuyu) rinse was performed. About 400 mg of MIL-101 powder and 30 mL of ethanol were placed in an autoclave at 393 K for 20 h. After cooling, the resulting product was centrifuged and washed with ethanol. Finally, the product was dried at 423 K overnight.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Sections

Synthesis of MIL-101

Chromium(III) nitrate nonahydrate (Cr(NO3)3⋅9H2O, >99.0%, from Tianjin), 1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, ≥99.0%, Acros Organic), and hydrofluoric acid (HF, 48%, from Merck) were used as received from vendors without further purification. The chromium-terephthalate MIL-101 was synthesized at 493 K for 60 min under microwave irradiation at 300 W. The molar composition of the reactant mixture was Cr(NO3)3⋅9H2O:H2BDC:HF:H2O 1:1:1:278. The reactant mixture was loaded into a Teflon autoclave, sealed, and placed in a microwave oven (Mars-5, CEM). The autoclave was heated to 493 K in 15 min and kept at this temperature for 60 min. After the reaction time, the reactor was cooled to room temperature. A fine green colored powder was obtained as the major product. To obtain high porosity, the as-synthesized MIL-101 was purified by using the reported method. Contents were completely transferred into a conical flask, and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, >99%, from Mallinckrodt) was added incrementally with continuous shaking to dissolve the H2BDC. By repeating washing with DMF and centrifugation, most of the terephthalic acid was removed from MIL-101. However, a significant amount of free H2BDC within the pores of MIL-101 was still found. To remove this extra H2BDC from the pores, an additional ethanol (>99.7, from Tianjin Fuyu) rinse was performed. About 400 mg of MIL-101 powder and 30 mL of ethanol were placed in an autoclave at 393 K for 20 h. After cooling, the resulting product was centrifuged and washed with ethanol. Finally, the product was dried at 423 K overnight.

cln_elements.content:
Adsorption equilibrium and diffusion of benzene on mesoporous chromium−terphthalate-based crystals (MIL-101) were experimentally studied by the gravimetric method in the pressure range up to 60.0 mbar. The MIL-101 crystals, whose sizes are about 100 nm, were synthesized by using microwave irradiation method. Adsorption isotherms and kinetic curves of benzene on the MIL-101 were measured experimentally. Results show that the maximum amount adsorbed of benzene on the synthesized MIL-101 was up to 16.5 mmol/g (or 176 wt %) at 288 K and 56.0 mbar. Diffusion coefficients of benzene within the MIL-101 were in the range of (4.25−4.76) × 10−9 cm2/s in 288−318 K with a lower activation energy of 2.41 kJ/mol. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) curves exhibited two separated peaks corresponding to two types of major adsorption sites for benzene adsorption on MIL-101. Consecutive cycles of adsorption−desorption experiment showed a fast desorption kinetics and high reversibility for benzene adsorption on MIL-101. The efficiency of benzene desorption from MIL-101 can reach 97%.

Recently, some novel materials with higher surface area, larger pore volume, and more uniform structure are being developed for VOCs treatment. Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) represent a fundamentally new class of nanoporous material. The crystalline porous materials are constructed from transition ions and bridging organic ligand, which have a vast, sturdy, and uniform framework structure. Owing to their extrahigh porosity and ordered and adjustable chemical functionality, MOFs now have the potential to various applications of gas storage, separations, and heterogeneous catalysis, especially in adsorption area. MIL-101 (Matérial Institut Lavoisier, chromium−terphthalate-based solid), a recent addition to MOFs, showed an extrahigh specific surface area and pore volume with the framework structure of microporous apertures and mesoporous cages. Additionally, this material was reported to be very stable at high temperature (up to 473K) and in the presence of different organic solvents (including water). Therefore, MIL-101 is attracting more attention in the potential application of gas adsorption. Férey et al. carried out high-pressure CO2 adsorption studies on MIL-101. The uptake of CO2 in MIL-101 has been shown to occur with a record capacity of 40 mmol/g at 5 MPa and 303 K. Chang et al. reported the benzene adsorption equilibrium on MIL-101 and revealed that this material had an intricate structure and demonstrates a huge, rapid adsorption of benzene, making it a good candidate for the removal of some harmful organic contaminants. However, no experimental data on diffusivities of organic compound in MIL-101 are available in the literature.

Adsorption Isotherms of Benzene on MIL-101

Figure shows adsorption isotherms of benzene vapor on the MIL-101 at different temperatures from 288 to 318 K measured experimentally. The experimental data show a type-I profile with a sharp increase in the uptake (at low benzene relative pressure) followed by a plateau. The maximum amount of adsorbed benzene is about 16.5 mmol/g at 288 K and 56.0 mbar. The adsorption capacity of benzene on the MIL-101 decreases with temperature, indicating a physisorption between benzene and MIL-101.

The data in Table indicate that the diffusion time constants (D M/r c 2) of benzene on MIL-101 are in range of (1.70−1.87) × 10−2 s−1. The corresponding diffusion coefficient (D M) is in the range of (1.70−1.87) × 10−9 cm2/s on the basis of the average particle radius r c of 5 μm, and the diffusion coefficient (D M) increases with temperature under the studied conditions. Benzene diffusion in MIL-101 is found to be an activated process.

Figure shows the linear dependences between ln D M and 1/T for benzene diffusing in the MIL-101 crystals. From the slope of the straight line, the activation energy (E a) of benzene diffusion in the MIL-101 is obtained, which is about 2.41 kJ/mol.

Figure depicts the corresponding linear dependencies of 1/T p versus ln(T p 2 R/βH) for benzene desorption from the MIL-101. From the slopes of the two lines, two kinds of desorption activation energies of benzene respectively on two kinds of adsorption sites of the MIL-101 can be found out separately. The activation energies of benzene desorption from the MIL-101 were 41.08 and 76.31 kJ/mol, respectively. The higher desorption activation energy means that it was more difficult for benzene to desorp from the corresponding adsorption sites of the MIL-101. That is to say, the benzene desorption from the adsorption sites of the Cr3+ metal centers is more difficult compared to benzene desorption from the adsorption sites of the framework pore surfaces.

Multiple Cycles of Benzene Adsorption−Desorption on MIL-101

Figure shows the variation curve of the amounts of benzene adsorbed on the MIL-101 obtained from five consecutive cycles of benzene adsorption−desorption experiments at 288 K. The consecutive adsorption−desorption processes were performed at 30 and 0.04 mbar, respectively, by switching on/off the vacuum pump in the IGA-003 system. It can be seen from Figure that the desorption rate of benzene is comparable to its adsorption rate on MIL-101. The amount of benzene adsorbed on the MIL-101 decreases sharply with time and then reaches a very low amount adsorbed quickly after 25s. The efficiency of benzene desorption can reach 97% over the entire five cycles. Meanwhile, Figure also shows that the equilibrium amount of benzene adsorbed was not changed significantly over five consecutive cycles of adsorption−desorption. It is clear that benzene uptake was reversible with very little accumulation of irreversible bound benzene on the MIL-101 frameworks, and it proves that the pressure swing is effective in stripping adsorbed benzene from the MIL-101. These properties can make MIL-101 an attractive candidate for treatment of VOCs emissions.

Conclusions

The MIL-101 sample prepared in this work shows an octahedral shape 100 nm in size with an extrahigh surface area of 4443 m2/g (langmuir). Its adsorption capacity of benzene is up to 16.5 mmol/g (or 176 wt %) at 288 K and 56.0 mbar, about twice the value for zeolites (silicalite-1 and SBA-15) and 3−5 times higher than that of activated carbons (Ajax and ACF) under similar conditions. Benzene diffusion within MIL-101 crystals is an activated process with diffusivity in the range of (4.25−4.67) × 10−9 cm2/s at 288−318 K and an activation energy for diffusion of 2.41 kJ/mol. The profile of the benzene TPD curve shows two separated peaks, suggesting that there mainly are two kinds of adsorption sites of benzene on MIL-101. The desorption activation energies of benzene corresponding to two types of adsorption sites are 41.08 and 76.31 kJ/mol, respectively. Consecutive cycles of adsorption−desorption show that a fast desorption kinetics, high desorption efficiency, and stable adsorption capacity over five cycles of adsorption−desorption are available, and the efficiency of benzene desorption can reach 97%, exhibiting an high reversibility of benzene adsorption−desorption on MIL-101.
